tossups.question: A city along this river is home to a statue made of 130 pieces of granite, the Five Ram Statue, as well as the Temple of the Five Immortals. Another city along this river is home to a pair of “Seafront Towers” that house the headquarters of the company Tencent and was the first Special Economic Zone established in its country. A third city on this river issues contactless payment cards usable at supermarkets, fast food stores, and subways, called (*) “octopus cards,” and is home to a district home built around the colonial “walled city” of Kowloon. That city along this river is governed by the “one country, two systems” policy and was handed over by its former colonial master, Britain, in 1997. For 10 points, name this primary river of Guangdong Province, whose delta is home to Hong Kong.
tossups.answer: Pearl River [or Zhu Jiang or Chu Kiang or Zyu Gong; prompt on Canton River] <WA, Geography>

tossups.question: When secondary amines (“uh-MEENS”) are used in the Zincke (“ZINK-uh”) reaction, the pyridine ring is opened to reveal a tertiary amine at one end and this functional group at the other. A cobalt catalyst converts alkenes and carbon monoxide into molecules with this functional group in the oxo process. This functional group can be protected by forming an acetal (“ASS-uh-tal”) by reaction with a (*) diol. Unlike the Jones reagent, pyridinium chlorochromate oxidizes alcohols to these compounds instead of carboxylic acids. The simplest compound with this functional group forms a preservative known as formalin. For 10 points, name this functional group, terminal examples of which are called aldehydes.
tossups.answer: carbonyls (“car-buh-NEELS”) [accept aldehydes until read; accept ketones] <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.question: Description acceptable. Repeated instances of this policy throughout the Thirty Years’ War resulted in the phenomenon of “tipper and seesaw time” or “Kipper und Wipper (“VIP-ur”).” A “Great” instance of this policy implemented under Henry VIII resulted in an observation commonly called Gresham’s Law. The solidus was introduced to try to reverse repeated instances of this sort of policy during the (*) Crisis of the Third Century, and was created during the reign of Diocletian. Typically, this policy was implemented as an alternative to taxation, and involved changing the process of creating such objects as the denarius by substituting copper or iron for more valuable metals, such as silver and gold. For 10 points, identify this practice of undermining the value of a monetary medium of exchange.
tossups.answer: currency debasement [or debasing currency; or debasing coinage; accept any answer indicating devaluing the currency or money supply; accept Great Debasement; prompt on inflation or fraud or printing money; do not accept or prompt on “counterfeiting” or “seigniorage”] <WA, European History>

tossups.question: James Fearon theorized that this activity resulted from commitment problems, uncertainty, and indivisibility of a good in his “bargaining model” of it. A 1959 book argues that the motivations of this activity can be separated into three “images” or levels of analysis, the first of which is individual. This is the third title noun of that pioneering Neorealist book by (*) Kenneth Waltz, in which it is paired with “man” and “the state.” Thomas Friedman posited that this activity has never occurred between countries with McDonald’s franchises, while another theory argues that this activity never takes place between democracies. For 10 points, give this activity defined as “the continuation of politics by other means” by a theorist of it, Carl von Clausewitz (“KLOW-zuh-vitz”).
tossups.answer: war [accept civil war; prompt on conflict or equivalents] <JM, Social Science: Political>

tossups.question: Early in his career, this author reworked Alice in Wonderland into political satires for the Westminster Gazette. A Sandie Byrne book about this “Unbearable” author coined the “feral ephebe” trope to characterize his early protagonists Reginald and Clovis. He parodied George Bernard Shaw’s play Man and Superman with his collection Beasts and Super-Beasts, which contains a story in which a girl describes her family (*) drowning in a bog while out hunting. This author, who created the polecat-ferret-worshipper Conradin, took his pen name from the Rubaiyat’s word for “cupbearer.” A story by him ends with the line “Romance at short notice was her specialty” after Framton Nuttel dashes from the Sappleton estate. For 10 points, name this British humorist of “Sredni Vashtar” and “The Open Window.”
tossups.answer: Saki [or H. H. Munro; or Hector Hugh Munro; accept The Unbearable Saki] <RK, Misc Lit>

tossups.question: Kingsley Amis suggested that a historian use the epigraph “I told you so, you fucking fools” for a book about this leader, who is criticized in a memoir titled for Conversations with him by Milovan Djilas (“MEE-loh-van JEE-lahs”). An analogy between a period of this leader’s rule and the French Revolution provides the title of a biography by Robert Conquest. This leader accused “saboteurs” of trying to overthrow him in a fabricated scheme he blamed on (*) Jewish physicians, known as the Doctor’s Plot. The term holodomor refers to a famine caused by the collectivization policies of leader, whose numerous crimes became better known after his successor delivered a “Secret Speech” about him. For 10 points, name this dictator whose reputation was harmed by the denunciation of his successor, Nikita Khrushchev.
tossups.answer: Joseph Stalin [or Iosif Besarionis dze Jughashvili] (The Conquest book is titled The Great Terror.) <JM, Historiography>

tossups.question: In a lively dance from a ballet by this composer, forty violins and a solo xylophone carry a syncopated rhythm that is interrupted by a brass fanfare. Another ballet by this composer ends with strings and flutes fading out, signifying that the characters are “quiet and strong.” A tomboy character dons a dress for the climactic dance of one of his ballets, which quotes the folk song “Bonaparte’s Retreat.” The original staging of another ballet by this composer featured a (*) sparse set including a house frame, a bench, and a rocking chair designed by Isamu Noguchi. His ballet music features a woodblock in “Hoe-Down” and a duet by the Husbandman and the Bride that introduces a theme and variations on the Shaker song “Simple Gifts.” For 10 points, name this American composer of Rodeo (“ro-DAY-oh”) and Appalachian Spring.
tossups.answer: Aaron Copland <WA, Other Arts: Music>

tossups.question: The first in an erotic collection of poems in this genre commands “Tell me you stones, / O speak, you towering palaces!” Another poem in this genre notes how “They urged me to those lips, with rapture crowned, / Deserted me, and hurled me to the ground” while recalling the author’s time in Marienbad (“MAH-ree-en-bod”). Friedrich Hölderlin’s poem “Bread and Wine” is in this form, as is a cycle of poems that Goethe wrote in Italy. A later poem in this genre asks “Have you remembered (*) Gaspara Stampa sufficiently yet” and claims that “beauty is nothing but the beginning of terror.” While living in the namesake castle on the Adriatic, an author wrote 10 mystical poems in this genre that begin by asking “Who, if I cried out, would hear me among the Angelic Orders?” For 10 points, Rainer Maria Rilke (“RYE-ner muh-REE-uh RIL-kuh”) used what genre for some poems written in Duino?
tossups.answer: elegy [or elegies; or Roman Elegies; or “Marienbad Elegy”; or Duino Elegies] <RK, Poetry>

tossups.question: The sixth of these figures is the credited author of a guide for everyday life and prayer titled “The Lantern of the Path.” The Four Deputies were used by one of these figures to contact his followers during the Minor Occultation. A ruler who was also one of these figures is venerated at a shrine in the city of Najaf. A father and son who were both legitimate possessors of this religious title were martyred at the Battle of (*) Karbala, which is mourned on the Day of Ashura. A “hidden” one of these figures is the focus of millenarianism among the “twelver” sect. These figures are regarded as the true successors of Ali by a sect that is dominant in Iraq and Iran. For 10 points, name these figures regarded as leaders of the Shia community, who share a name with Sunni religious men who lead prayers at mosques.
tossups.answer: imams [accept Shi’a imams; prompt on Mahdis or saviors; prompt on answers that refer to Shi’a leaders until “Shi’a”; do not accept or prompt on “prophets”] <JM, Religion>

tossups.question: Several models of this entity, including the 720-degree HDGM, use data from the ESA’s Swarm project. Julius Bartels developed a measure of fluctuations of horizontal components of this entity called the K-index. Models of this entity usually record its dip and declination and try to take secular variation into account. The fact that this entity isn’t perfectly concentric results in the South Atlantic (*) Anomaly, where this entity is weakened by the Van Allen belts. This entity is created by the rotation of the iron in the liquid outer core according to the dynamo theory. This entity creates “stripes” in mid-oceanic ridges when it reverses polarity. For 10 points, name this entity, which a compass uses to point north.
tossups.answer: Earth’s magnetic field [or geomagnetic field or geomagnetism; or Earth’s magnetosphere; prompt on ferromagnetism or magnetic field or magnetosphere or magnetic pole or pole] <EM, Earth Science>

tossups.question: It’s not love, but in a set of works titled Edifying Discourses, a philosopher expanded upon his view of this concept as a form of “madness,” quoting Plato’s Phaedrus. Having this concept allows a process of repetition that affirms the self as “a relation which relates itself to itself.” Figures who exemplify this concept are [emphasize] contrasted with Agamemnon, who accepts the loss of Iphigenia. An author named Johannes (*) Climacus defines this concept as an “absurdity, held in the passion of inwardness.” Having this concept lets one maintain a “teleological suspension of the ethical,” as exemplified by Abraham, who is posited in Fear and Trembling as one of this concept’s “knights.” For 10 points, name this type of conviction often discussed by Søren Kierkegaard, who posited a “leap” of it.
tossups.answer: faith [accept Kierkegaardian faith or knight of faith or leap of faith; prompt on religious belief] <ML, Phil/Thought>

tossups.question: Bartolomé Arzáns de Orsúa (“ar-SAHNS de or-SOO-ah”) recounts an incident in which he felt nauseous after being peer pressured into consuming this good by miners who said that not doing so would ruin their metal. A president from the Movement to Socialism developed a slogan saying “yes to” this crop, which he formerly farmed. Since 2000, campaigns against this good using drones to spray glyphosate (“GLY-fuh-sate”) from the air have brualized peasants who grow it. John Stith (*) Pemberton combined a west African nut with this good to form the name of his most famous invention. This crop was used as a stimulant by miners at Potosí in Bolivia, whose current president, Evo Morales, is an enthusiastic promoter of chewing it. For 10 points, name this crop that Pablo Escobar processed into a drug often sourced from Colombia.
tossups.answer: coca leaves [accept cocaine; prompt on Coca-Cola; do not accept “cocoa” or “cacao”] <JM, World History>

tossups.question: For a plasma, this quantity is proportional to the square root of the quantity [read slowly] “adiabatic index times charge state times electron temperature divided by the ratio of ion mass to proton mass.” A horizontal layer in which this quantity is minimized is the SOFAR channel. For a fluid, this quantity is equal to the square root of the ratio of its bulk modulus divided by its density. A common classroom setup to measure this quantity uses a (*) transparent pipe, blocked at one end with a piston and filled with a small amount of fine powder, known as Kundt’s tube. This quantity can be calculated as 331 plus 0.6 times the temperature in degrees Celsius. The ratio of an object’s velocity to this quantity is known as its Mach number. For 10 points, name this quantity that is equal to about 343 meters per second at room temperature.
tossups.answer: speed of sound [prompt on speed; accept Mach 1 until “Mach” is read; do not accept or prompt on “velocity” or “velocity of sound”] <RN, Physics>

tossups.question: An author with this first name wrote a novel set in the rundown Hotel Splendour, where an aged man drinks and recalls the song “Beautiful María of My Soul.” A protagonist with this first name jumps off a bridge in New Brunswick and is beaten in a cane field, but is saved both times by a golden mongoose. An author with this first name created two Cuban musicians who perform on I Love Lucy after emigrating to Harlem in his novel The (*) Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love. A character with this first name falls in love with the prostitute Ybón (“ee-BONE”) after graduating from Rutgers as a virgin. That overweight sci-fi and comic book nerd with this first name has a fukú curse put on his family by Rafael Trujillo (“troo-HEE-yo”). For 10 points, a Dominican boy with what first name is the subject of a Junot Díaz (“JOO-noh DEE-azz”) novel about his “Brief Wondrous Life”?
tossups.answer: Oscar [accept Oscar de León or Oscar Wao or Oscar Hijuelos] <RK, Long Fiction>

tossups.question: This person gifted Austin W. Curtis with the royalties of a book about him to allow Curtis to move to Detroit and start a business. This person, who was glorified in the article “A Boy Who Was Traded for a Horse,” created a “Jesup wagon” to demonstrate his creations. This person’s namesake museum, which was given land by FDR, was devastated by a fire that destroyed many of his paintings. This person, who sent out a list of namesake “bulletins” to (*) farmers, proposed methods that helped alleviate a boll weevil blight by switching crops. Time magazine called him the “Black Leonardo” for his work at a university where he supposedly pioneered over 100 forms of peanut products. For 10 points, name this associate of Booker T. Washington who worked at the Tuskegee Institute.
tossups.answer: George Washington Carver <ML, US History>

tossups.question: One story claims that this goddess came from Hyperborea (“hyper-bore-ee-uh”) with a great pack of wolves, which Antonius Liberalis connected to her journey to Lycia. When this goddess was depleted, Themis aided her by bringing nectar and ambrosia from heaven. Callimachus’s fourth hymn describes this goddess’s travels through Thessaly, after which she went to a place anchored by four granite pillars sent by Poseidon. After this goddess’s lover turned her into a quail and (*) impregnated her, she was chased by the Python across Greece. She wandered the world before coming to the island of Delos, as Hera had forbidden her from giving birth on solid land after her affair with Zeus. Niobe boasted of giving birth to more children than, for 10 points, what mother of the twin deities Apollo and Artemis?
tossups.answer: Leto <WA, Myths/Legends>

tossups.question: This artist showed a muscular woman gazing back over her left shoulder in a red chalk sketch of a mythical figure from Libya. Rudolf Wittkower’s studies of the evolution of one of this artist’s designs focuses on his unconventional plan for a ricetto (“ree-CHET-oh”) or vestibule. For that building, this artist created reclining nudes depicting Day, Night, Dusk, and Dawn, as well as an overlapping oval design for a Mannerist (*) staircase. This artist, who included five sibyls among the twelve prophets he painted around a massive ceiling, designed the Laurentian Library. St. Bartholomew holds his own flayed skin in a massive fresco painted by this artist that shows Jesus casting sinners on the right into Hell. For 10 points, name this Florentine artist who painted a massive Last Judgment in the Sistine Chapel.
tossups.answer: Michelangelo [or Michelangelo Buonarotti] <AR, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.question: In one story, an old man encourages Toby Dammit to recite a phrase referencing this character shortly before he is decapitated while jumping a turnstile. This character abducts a man who lies to a ruined land-speculator that he has not “made a farthing” off him. In another appearance, this character reads a politician’s palm and foresees the death of his sons. In that story, King Philip and Blackbeard are (*) summoned by this character as part of a group of twelve “American” jurors led by Justice Hathorne (“HAY-thorn”) of the Salem Witch trials. A selfish man receives Captain Kidd’s treasure from this character in exchange for becoming a usurer (“YOO-zhur-ur”) in a story by Washington Irving. For 10 points, name this figure who makes a deal with Jabez (“JAY-bezz”) Stone and loses a court case to Daniel Webster in a story by Stephen Vincent Benét (“ben-AY”).
tossups.answer: the Devil [or Old Scratch; or Mr. Scratch; accept “Never Bet the Devil Your Head”] <NC, Short Fiction>

tossups.question: In early 2019, Ionis (“eye-OH-niss”) Pharmaceuticals began clinical trials for an antisense oligonucleotide-based therapy for this disease. An unusual disease similar to this one in Black South Africans is caused by mutations in JPH3. Inhibition of VMAT2 (“V-mat-2”) by tetrabenazine (“tetra-ben-uh-zeen”) is one treatment for this disease. Because the gene that encodes a protein central to this disease is more unstable in spermatogenesis than oogenesis (“oh-oh-genesis”), children of an affected father have an earlier age of onset, a phenomenon called (*) paternal anticipation. The striatum is damaged early in this disease, which is caused by the expansion of a CAG repeat in the polyglutamine tract of the protein HTT. For 10 points, name this autosomal dominant disease whose sufferers experience involuntary movements called chorea (“COR-ee-uh”).
tossups.answer: Huntington’s disease <RN, Biology: Genetics/Cell>

tossups.question: In one of this piece’s slow movements, harp-like flutes oscillate B and A half-diminished chords in a plodding ostinato that builds up to a climax with tubular bells. This piece’s fourth movement begins with layers of rising, shimmering violins cycling groups of three 16th notes like “E, G, A” before the horns introduce four bouncy themes in triple meter before a majestic “hymn” trio section. Low strings and timpani maintain a steadily (*) crescendoing G ostinato in a “short-short-short long, long, short-short long” pattern to open this piece’s first movement, which shares its 5/4 (“five-four”) time signature with its final movement, which ends with a choral fadeout and is subtitled “The Mystic.” A section about “The Bringer of Jollity” appears in, for 10 points, what Gustav Holst suite that opens with “Mars, The Bringer of War”?
tossups.answer: The Planets <WA, Classical/Opera>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: This term was first used to describe a press conference that contained the phrase “peace is at hand.” For 10 points each:
answer: Lyndon LaRouche [or Lyndon Hermyle LaRouche Jr.]
Henry Kissinger [or Heinz Alfred Kissinger] <AA, US History>
parts: Give this two-word term for a revelation during a presidential campaign that significantly shifts the public’s perception of a candidate. It is named for the month before a presidential election.

This fringe activist created the “October Surprise” conspiracy theory alleging that Ronald Reagan colluded with Iran to keep hostages in custody until he was elected. This leader of the National Council of Labor Committees frequently ran “ego-stripping” sessions on his followers.

The “peace is at hand” press conference was headlined by this National Security Advisor to Richard Nixon, who was later awarded the Nobel Peace Prize with Lê Đức Thọ (“lay duck taw”) for negotiating an end to the Vietnam War.

bonuses.leadin: Will Eisner’s graphic novel adaptation of this epic begins with its antagonist being granted magical powers from the Great Grey Rock of Evil. For 10 points each:
answer: Epic of Sundiata [or Sundiata: An Epic of Old Mali; or anything indicating an epic about Sundiata; accept Sunjata, Son-Jara, or Mari Diata in place of “Sundiata”]
Amos Tutuola (The unnamed novel is The Palm-Wine Drinkard.) <JM, Misc Lit>
parts: Name this epic about a crippled child who goes on to kill the Sosso king Soumaoro and found the Mali Empire. It is one of many tales orally preserved by bards known as griots (“GREE-ohs”).
Many stories in West African oral tradition are about this trickster god who typically took the form of a spider.

Yoruban (“YO-roo-bin”) oral tradition inspired much of this author’s work, such as a novel about a boy abandoned in a supernatural realm titled My Life in the Bush of Ghosts. In this author’s first novel, a rich man travels to Dead’s Town.

bonuses.leadin: Ludwig van Beethoven’s An die ferne Geliebte (“ahn dee FAIR-nuh guh-LEEB-tuh”) is considered to be the first of these collections by a major composer. For 10 points each:
answer: song cycles [or Liederkreis or Liederzyklus; prompt on lied or lieder]
parts: Give the common term for these collections of pieces. Examples of them based on the works of Wilhelm Müller include Winterreise (“VIN-tuh-RYE-zuh”) and Die schöne Müllerin (“dee SHUR-nuh MYOO-ler-in”).

This incredibly prolific composer wrote those song cycles, which number among his more than 600 extant vocal pieces. He also wrote seven symphonies, including an “Unfinished” one, before dying young at age 31.

This posthumously (“POSS-chuh-miss-lee”) published song cycle by Schubert includes “Die Taubenpost” (“dee TAO-bin-post”), a musical depiction of pigeons that is often considered to be the last song Schubert wrote. Its settings of poems by Heinrich Heine (“HY-nuh”) include “Der Atlas” and “Der Doppelgänger.”

bonuses.leadin: The anti-IL4 receptor antibody dupilumab is used to treat this disease if emollients and topical steroids don’t work, and its asteatotic (“ass-tee-uh-TOT-ick”) variant tends to occur in the winter. For 10 points each:
answer: herpes simplex virus [accept HSV-1 or HSV-2] <EM, Biology: Medicine>
parts: Name this disease in which an itchy, flaky red rash occurs on flexural surfaces. Along with allergies and asthma, it makes up the atopic (“ay-TOP-ick”) triad.
High levels of this rarest antibody isotype are associated with the diseases of the atopic triad.
An eruption named for Kaposi, but [emphasize] not Kaposi’s sarcoma, is caused by a superinfection of eczema lesions with this virus. This virus also causes cold sores on the lips and genital lesions.

bonuses.leadin: In a notation used in this subfield, the first things written down are the basic facts about the world in which an exchange is taking place. For 10 points each:
answer: pragmatics [do not accept or prompt on “pragmatism”]
J. L. Austin [or John Langshaw Austin] <JM, Social Science: Linguistics>
parts: Name this subfield of linguistics that studies both the context in which utterances are made, and the implications of that context. This subfield studies deictic (“DIKE-tick”) expressions like “here” or “that.”
Pragmatics is closely related to this other subfield of linguistics, which studies the meaning of utterances.
This analytic philosopher’s theory of “performative utterances” is central to the field of pragmatics, and was introduced in his lecture series published under the title How to Do Things With Words.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about polling mishaps in US elections, for 10 points each.
answer: having a college education [or equivalents such as tertiary education or university education or having a bachelor’s degree; prompt on educated or schooling]
social desirability bias [prompt on desirability bias] <WA, Other Academic>
parts: In one such mishap, Gallup only sampled households with a landline phone and thus underestimated this President, who defeated Thomas Dewey to win re-election in 1948.

In 2016, most polls underestimated Donald Trump’s performance in the Midwest by oversampling white voters with this trait, who were more likely to both respond to polls and vote Democratic. A description is fine.

Polled voters may have been loath to admit to strangers that they were voting for Trump, which would exemplify this kind of response bias in which one gives answers based on perceived approval by others. Supposed examples of this bias include the Bradley effect and the “Shy Tory” effect in Britain.

bonuses.leadin: A function has this property if its second derivative is positive on its entire domain. For 10 points each:
answer: convex [or concave-upward; do not accept or prompt on just “concave”]
parts: Name this property held by functions such as e-to-the-x that lie above their tangent lines. In a polygon with this property, all interior angles are at most 180 degrees.
In a probabilistic setting, this inequality states that for a convex function phi and a random variable X, phi of the expectation of X is less than or equal to the expectation of phi of X.

Jensen’s inequality can be used to prove Holder’s inequality, which reduces to this inequality when p and q are equal to two. This inequality, named for two mathematicians, states that the dot product of u and v is at most the magnitude of u times the magnitude of v.

bonuses.leadin: A “protocol” named for this city called for Israel to invade Egypt, after which Britain and France would issue disingenuous statements that they had to seize the Suez Canal to maintain its neutrality. For 10 points each:
answer: Mustafa Kemal Atatürk [or Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]

metric system [accept SI or International System of Units or Système internationale d’unités; accept mks or cgs or meter–kilogram–second or centimeter–gram–second system; prompt on kilogram and meter] <JM, European History>
parts: Name this French city. A treaty named for this city confirmed an armistice signed in Moudros Harbor and divided a country into Italian, French, British, and Greek zones of occupation.

This leader deposed the signers of the Treaty of Sèvres and stripped them of their citizenship. He did so after coming to power in a war that ended with the burning of Smyrna and the signing of the more favorable Treaty of Lausanne (“lo-ZANN”).

Sèvres houses the International Bureau of Weights and Measures, which stores platinum-iridium cylinders that served to officially define the units of this system, which was formalized by an 1875 convention in nearby Paris.

bonuses.leadin: In an oft-excerpted parable from this story, a dying emperor sends a message to you, “his miserable subject,” only for the messenger to take an eternity to reach you. For 10 points each:
answer: “The Great Wall of China” [or “Beim Bau der Chinesischen Mauer”]
parts: Name this Franz Kafka story whose elderly narrator compares excessive consideration of leadership to a rising river that “overflows its banks” and emphasizes the “piecemeal construction” of the title structure.

In two essays, this Argentine analyzed Qin Shi Huang’s (“cheen shurr hwong’s”) decision to build the Great Wall and identified Lord Dunsany (“dun-SAY-nee”) and Robert Browning as among Kafka’s “Precursors.” This author wrote the stories in Ficciones (“feeks-YO-nays”).

Scared of its ability to scale the Great Wall, Emperor Yuan destroys the title invention in this author’s “The Flying Machine.” Eckels panics while on a “Time Safari” hunting dinosaurs in his story “A Sound of Thunder.”

bonuses.leadin: José Guadalupe Posada created a satirical zinc etching of one of these figures in a fancy hat. For 10 points each:
answer: André Breton (The quote is from his Manifesto of Surrealism.) <AR, Painting/Sculpture>
parts: Give these figures, one of whom is laden with explosives and sleeps on a bunk bed in a painting titled The Dream. They appear in many Mexican paintings, such as Dream of a Sunday Afternoon in Alameda Park.
This Mexican muralist and husband of Frida Kahlo painted Dream of a Sunday Afternoon in the Central Alameda, as well as the controversial Man at the Crossroads.

This artist greatly admired the skeleton art of Mexico during his four-month tour of the country in 1938, during which he became friends with Frida Kahlo. Leonora Carrington was a major exponent of a movement that this artist claimed exhibited “pure psychic automatism.”

bonuses.leadin: During a hunt, this character encounters a pack of white dogs with red ears feeding on a stag. For 10 points each:
answer: Pwyll [or Pwyll pen Annwn (“pwill pen ah-NOON”)]
Wales [or Cymru; prompt on Britain or UK or United Kingdom]
parts: Name this lord of Dyfed (“DIV-id”) who switches kingdoms and likenesses with Arawn for a year. During that time, he kills Hafgan and refuses to sleep with Arawn’s wife.
Pwyll is a character in the first branch of the Mabinogion, which is a source for the mythology of this country whose cities include Cardiff.
Pwyll meets this character when he goes to a hill that causes those with royal blood to either see miracles or receive wounds. This wife of Pwyll gives birth to his son Pryderi (“prih-DARE-ee”).

bonuses.leadin: This philosopher discussed a number of “refutations which are really fallacies instead” in his Sophistical Refutations. For 10 points each:
answer: logic [accept Aristotelian logic or Boolean logic]
Porphyry of Tyre [or Porphyrios of Tyre] (That textbook is the Isagoge.) <WA, Phil/Thought>
parts: Name this philosopher who enumerated ten different types of things that can be the subjects or predicates of propositions in his treatise Categories.

Sophistical Refutations and Categories are part of Aristotle’s Organon, which is a set of writings on this discipline. George Boole, who names a variety of this discipline, wrote about it in The Laws of Thought.
This philosopher’s major work, which is an introduction to Aristotle’s Categories, served as the major introductory medieval textbook on logic. He also edited the Enneads of his teacher Plotinus.

bonuses.leadin: This author’s poem “The Rhodora” describes a “rival of the rose” brought into the world by the “self-same Power” that brought the speaker. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author who set a poem about the Revolutionary War by a “rude bridge that arched the flood” where “embattled farmers… fired the shot heard round the world.”
Emerson included an “Earth-Song” in his poem “Hamatreya,” which was inspired by this religion whose scriptures include the Bhagavad Gita.

The speaker of Emerson’s “Brahma” claims the “red slayer” and “the slain” don’t know the “ways I keep, and pass” and perform this two-word action. T. S. Eliot’s “Ash Wednesday” opens, “Because I do not hope” to perform this two-word action.

bonuses.leadin: This building’s design was inspired by the symmetry of the desert flower genus Hymenocalis. For 10 points each:
answer: Willis Tower [or Sears Tower] <WA, Other Arts: Architecture>
parts: Name this skyscraper designed by Adrian Smith that was finished in 2010. This building’s setbacks are placed in an upward spiraling pattern, inspired in part by the Great Mosque of Samarra.

The Burj Khalifa was designed by this architecture firm whose architects, Bruce Graham and Fazlur Khan, created many skyscrapers that exemplify the concept of “structural art.” This firm also employed pioneering woman architect Natalie de Blois, who co-designed its Lever House.
Perhaps the best-known US skyscraper by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill is this Chicago building, which was the tallest in the world for 25 years and was renamed in 2009.

bonuses.leadin: This sect’s most famous dance is meant to achieve a form of ecstasy known as wajd. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mystical Islamic sect whose Mevlevi Order emphasizes experiencing Allah through emotional experiences like whirling to the music of a ney, or Turkish flute. It was heavily promoted by Rumi.

In 1898, the Klickitat Native American Jake Hunt founded a religion based on spinning while holding a pair of these objects. In Lakota tradition, these objects are used to adorn sacred pipes as symbols of the Great Spirit.
The Yanvalou (“yon-vah-loo”) dance is used to invoke these spirits, who each have different types of dances associated with them, including some wild spinning motions. They include Damballah.

bonuses.leadin: The outcome of a case regarding this practice was strongly influenced by the judge’s relation to the heiress of the Lindsay family, Dido Elizabeth Belle. For 10 points each:
answer: slave trade [or slavery; accept kidnapping people and selling them into slavery; prompt on kidnapping]
parts: Name this practice, one route for which was called the Middle Passage. It was part of the Triangle Trade.

This case outlawed the slave trade in Britain. It was decided by Judge Mansfield, who possibly originated the quote “Let justice be done though the heavens fall,” describing his commitment to his unpopular ruling.
This other prominent British abolitionist allied himself with the writer of “Amazing Grace,” John Newton. He died just after the Abolition Act of 1833 was assured to pass.

bonuses.leadin: This functional group is formed from the acid-catalyzed rearrangement of an oxime (“OX-eem”) in the Beckmann reaction. For 10 points each:
answer: cyclohexane [do not accept or prompt on “hexane”] <RN, Chemistry>
parts: Name this functional group found in the peptide bonds of proteins.
This amide is a commonly used polar aprotic (“ay-PRO-tick”) solvent. It reacts with phosphorus oxychloride to formylate benzene in the Vilsmeier–Haack reaction.

DMF is considered a fluxional (“FLUCK-shuh-null”) molecule because its two methyl groups continually switch places. Another example of fluxionality is the chair flipping of this cyclic hydrocarbon whose formula is C6H12.

bonuses.leadin: This character “Proposes a Toast” in a follow-up that the author wrote to critique trends in public education. For 10 points each:
answer: C. S. Lewis [or Clive Staples Lewis]
Cupid AND Psyche [accept Eros in place of “Cupid”] <AR, Long Fiction>
parts: Name this senior employee at the “Lowerarchy” (“lower-ark-ee”) who, in one scene, turns into a centipede “in the heat of composition” of a letter. He advises Wormwood on how best to tempt “the Patient” into sin in an epistolary novel.
This author of The Screwtape Letters wrote seven fantasy novels that chronicle the land of Narnia.

In his novel Till We Have Faces, C. S. Lewis depicted the story of these two lovers from the perspective of Orual. Lucius listens to an old woman telling the story of these two people to comfort Charite (“KAH-ree-tay”) in a Latin novel.

bonuses.leadin: The theory of these objects is combined with supersymmetry in a formulation of M-theory that provides a theory of everything that, unfortunately, is probably false. For 10 points each:
answer: strings [accept string theory; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, branes]
branes [accept membranes; accept P-branes or D-branes]
loops [accept loop quantum gravity; accept answers like closed or circle] <WA, Physics>
parts: Name these tiny vibrating one-dimensional objects whose namesake theories are one possible formulation of quantum gravity.
In M-theory, strings can be thought of as one-dimension examples of these mathematical objects, which generalize the notion of a point particle to any number p of dimensions.

Because the strings that comprise gravitons form these structures, gravitons are not bound to any particular brane. These structures also name a galaxy-brain theory of gravity that models spacetime using spin networks.

bonuses.leadin: One of these entities, the Majeerteen (“ma-jair-TAIN”), are the subject of widespread resentment due to their historical role in governing. For 10 points each:
answer: Somali clans [accept qabiil; prompt on Somali tribes]
parts: Identify these entities, two of which are named for Sheikh Darod (“da-ROAD”) and Sheikh Ishaq. Some of these entities have established autonomy in the breakaway state of Jubaland.
This country’s emperor Haile Selassie agreed to set territorial boundaries with Italian-controlled Somalia in exchange for assistance in controlling hostile Somali clans.

The Darod clan is one of the dominant clans in this territory of Somalia that, like its neighbor Somaliland, is recognized internationally as an autonomous state. This territory takes its name from an ancient land thought to be in present-day Somalia that is described in Egyptian texts.
